SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Feeling out of sorts, fatigue, and lightheadedness.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He has been involved in home renovation projects and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to the construction in his kitchen. He denies fever, chills, and shortness of breath but reports occasional chest cramps and a slight cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses occasional chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm. 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema of the bilateral lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Ejection fraction of 45%. Mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with fatigue, lightheadedness, and physical exam findings consistent with fluid retention. The chest x-ray shows fluid in the lungs, and the echocardiogram demonstrates reduced ejection fraction and mitral regurgitation.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily. The patient should weigh himself daily and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms.
• Additional Testing: Order a repeat echocardiogram.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure appears to be well managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. The patient should continue to monitor blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was trying to change a light bulb on a ladder and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin for it. She has had a rhinoplasty in the past.

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows significant tenderness to the medial aspect of the knee. Pain is present with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Sensation is normal in the lower extremity.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment is normal.

IMPRESSION

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended a knee brace and temporary use of crutches for the next couple of days. The patient will follow up in one week, and if not improved, an MRI will be ordered. I prescribed Motrin 800 mg to be taken every six hours with food for two weeks. The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports that the pain started after lifting heavy boxes on Saturday. He heard a pop and experienced pain, which has persisted since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and Icy Hot, but the pain has not significantly improved. The patient also reports tingling in his right toes, which resolved on Sunday.

Regarding his diabetes, the patient admits to not having the best diet recently due to helping his daughter and being on the go. He has been taking his blood pressure medication but sometimes forgets on weekends. The patient's osteoarthritis in the knee has been manageable, with occasional aggravation from physical activity.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain and knee pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes (resolved).
• Psychiatric: Denies depression or anxiety.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.
• Neurological: No focal deficits.

RESULTS

Blood pressure: Elevated in the office.

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8.

Back x-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Back pain (lumbar strain).
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's history and physical exam are consistent with a lumbar strain from lifting heavy boxes.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's hemoglobin A1c is elevated, indicating suboptimal control of diabetes.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day and repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure readings are elevated, and he sometimes forgets to take his medication on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up on depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports managing his depression well with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling with hypertension, but his blood pressure has improved. He exercises regularly, running 4-5 miles a day, and experiences shortness of breath with exertion, especially in humid conditions. He also reports some chest pounding during exercise, which usually resolves.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion and chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Denies cough, wheezing, or other respiratory symptoms.
• Neurological: Denies dizziness, seizures, or other neurological symptoms.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, well-managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his depression well with Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription as needed.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is exercising regularly and has no concerning respiratory symptoms.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure has improved, and he is taking Norvasc regularly.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication and monitor blood pressure.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents with right finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski strap caught on her finger, causing it to bend back. This occurred on Sunday. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. The pain is worse with movement.

The patient also reports a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Appendectomy at age 18.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Endorses constipation.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right finger pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right hand: No fractures noted. Normal alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents with right finger pain after a skiing incident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: Based on the patient's history, physical examination, and normal x-ray findings, the diagnosis is a contusion on the tip of the right index finger.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe an aluminum foam splint and Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverish feelings, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences increased sensitivity to cold and worsening anxiety and depression. She has been taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12 supplements.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hysterectomy in 1996.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of anemia and is currently experiencing symptoms consistent with iron deficiency anemia.
• Additional Testing: Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Referral: Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidentally discovered pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with no significant past medical history, who presents today with worsening headaches over the past few months and a newly discovered pituitary lesion. The patient denies any history of headaches in the past. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, with a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago, and has been worsening over time. The headaches tend to be worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed recently bumping into door frames.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss. Endorses worsening headaches.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Denies any issues.
• Cardiovascular: Denies any issues.
• Respiratory: Denies any issues.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies any issues.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies any issues.
• Neurological: Endorses bumping into door frames.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
• Cranial Nerves: Grossly intact.
• Motor and Sensory: No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.
• Visual: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with worsening headaches and a newly discovered pituitary lesion.

Pituitary adenoma.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a benign-appearing pituitary adenoma, incidentally discovered during workup for worsening headaches. He is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
• Surgical Intervention: Transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to monitor vision before and after surgery.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended surgical intervention plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up with the surgery scheduler and eye doctor as instructed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, who presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved after four days. She has not had any recurrence of these symptoms since then. The patient was under significant stress due to a job transition at the time of the symptoms. The ER conducted an EKG and blood tests, which were normal.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss. Endorses stress and fatigue.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain in October 2020, resolved.
• Gastrointestinal: Endorses difficulty swallowing in October 2020, resolved. Denies abdominal pain. Normal bowel movements.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain, swelling, or muscle pain.
• Neurological: Denies lightheadedness or dizziness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No tenderness in the lower abdomen.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, who presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect the patient had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.
• Follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation for possible kidney anomalies in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has been seen by multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. The patient's mother reports that Katherine has normal wet diaper frequency (8-10 per day) and drinks an adequate amount of fluids. The family is here for a kidney evaluation due to the potential for congenital anomalies associated with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Genitourinary: Reports normal wet diaper frequency (8-10 per day).
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General Appearance: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Due to the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract associated with this chromosomal deletion syndrome, we will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

Patient Agreements: The patient's mother understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a patient who presents with right wrist pain and swelling after a fall while carrying laundry down the stairs. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has not had any previous injuries to this arm. The patient rates the pain as a 9 out of 10 in severity. She has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. There is no extension of pain, but she reports some tingling in her fingers. The patient has difficulty moving her wrist in any direction without experiencing extreme pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Obvious swelling and bruising of the right wrist. Tenderness on palpation throughout. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus felt.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

1. Apply a brace to the right wrist for support and immobilization.
2. Schedule surgery for the patient as soon as possible.
3. Prescribe 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours for pain management.
4. Begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery, with an assessment to determine frequency.
5. Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks to assess progress and discuss vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Wear the brace for 6 weeks.
2. Attend physical therapy as recommended.
3. Take pain medication as prescribed.
4. Return for follow-up appointment in 4 weeks.
5. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain following a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 48-year-old male who presents with right knee pain after slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced pain with flexion and extension of the knee since then. The patient has been taking ibuprofen for pain and swelling.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, pain with flexion and extension, edema around the knee, and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's history, physical exam, and x-ray findings suggest a medial collateral ligament strain.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day. Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently taking Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 during the visit, but the patient reports taking medication regularly.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the importance of diet modification, including reducing sodium intake.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a patient who presents with left shoulder pain for approximately three weeks. He is unsure of any specific injury but has been active and working on renovating his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol couldn't alleviate. The pain is constant and worsens when he tries to put pressure on the shoulder or reach for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which helps to take the edge off but does not completely relieve the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in the arm or hand.

PAST HISTORY

Not reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Active lifestyle, currently renovating basement.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not reported.

MEDICATIONS

Extra strength Tylenol as needed for pain.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
Neurovascular exam of left arm: Capillary refill less than 3 seconds. Sensation intact to light touch.

RESULTS

Shoulder x-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient presents with left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. An MRI of the left shoulder will be ordered to further evaluate the issue. The patient will be referred to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks and may continue to take Tylenol for pain management. If symptoms do not improve, a steroid injection for the shoulder may be considered. The patient will be provided with educational materials on physical therapy and will schedule a follow-up visit after completing the therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes who presents with occasional left knee pain. The pain occurs less than once a day, mainly when walking, and causes the knee to feel like it is giving out. The patient reports that the pain passes quickly and has not had any significant impact on daily activities. However, she is concerned about an upcoming trip that involves walking and line dancing, and she does not want to risk exacerbating the knee pain. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any pain medication for it.

Regarding her hypertension, the patient reports that her blood pressure has been stable, around 120/70, and she takes her medications regularly at 8:30 AM and 8:30 PM. She is currently on Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, and Hydrochlorothiazide.

For her diabetes, the patient reports that her fasting blood sugar has been running a little higher at about 130. She takes Metformin along with her blood pressure medications.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee pain, no swelling or redness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee with no ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain.
   • Medical Reasoning: Likely arthritis in the left knee.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily. Consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure stable on current medications.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.

3. Diabetes Mellitus.
   • Medical Reasoning: Fasting blood sugar slightly elevated.
   • Additional Testing: Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess the need for adjustments to Metformin.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. She reports minimal cough and sore throat today.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial Fibrillation

MEDICATIONS

Digoxin

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Minimal cough, sore throat, no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: No difficulty swallowing, decreased appetite.
Constitutional: Mild fatigue, no nausea or vomiting.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: Not provided
Temperature: Not provided
Heart Rate: Not provided
Oxygen Saturation: Within normal limits

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation.
Extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for possible surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve cough and shortness of breath.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times daily to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up at the next scheduled visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal lab work - low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 40-year-old female who presents for evaluation of low immunoglobulin A level, as noted by her primary care physician during a recent physical. The patient reports a history of frequent colds, particularly in the wintertime, which tend to linger for extended periods. She denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. The patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and has been started on metformin. She has no known family history of immune deficiencies.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient's family owns a donut shop. She recently traveled to Zambia.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: No fever, vitals within normal limits.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

ASSESSMENT

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
2. Type 2 diabetes.

PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level: Order additional blood work to check other antibodies. Educate the patient on the potential risks associated with blood products and the importance of informing healthcare providers of her iga deficiency. Monitor for any changes in infection frequency or severity, and any changes in abdominal symptoms.
2. Type 2 diabetes: Continue metformin as prescribed. Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy diet and monitor blood sugar levels.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up after lab work is completed. Notify the healthcare provider of any new symptoms or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents today for an evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports that he has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, and over the past week, he has developed elbow pain. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain has been present for about four days and is rated as a 6/10 in severity. The pain keeps him up at night and interferes with his daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief, which provides minimal relief.

PAST HISTORY

None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Hobbies: Pottery and ceramics.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.

Musculoskeletal: Moderate tenderness to palpation over the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fractures or bony abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow.

PLAN

1. Rest: The patient is advised to rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Ice: Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Medication: Ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for one week.
4. Activity modification: The patient is advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to reassess the patient's progress.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow the prescribed treatment plan and schedule a follow-up appointment in one week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain, shortness of breath, and recent fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a middle-aged male who presents today for evaluation of chest pain, shortness of breath, and a recent fall. He reports experiencing chest pain while walking outside, which he initially dismissed as heartburn. He also experienced shortness of breath but continued walking until he fell. He was seen in the emergency department, where it was noted that his ankles were swollen. His blood pressure was 200/90. He has a history of hypertension and is currently taking Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc.

David admits to not consistently taking his medications and not following a strict diet. He consumes salty foods, such as chips, and has not been monitoring his blood pressure at home. He denies any sleep issues and reports quitting smoking a few years ago, with occasional lapses.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Blood pressure 128/72, other vitals within normal limits.
Neck: No jugular venous distention.
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
Extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram from the emergency department visit shows preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

1. Chest pain and shortness of breath likely secondary to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
2. Hypertension, currently on Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc.

PLAN

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Encourage patient to take medications consistently.
2. Consult nutritionist for dietary advice and monitoring.
3. Obtain a blood pressure cuff for home monitoring and encourage patient to track blood pressure regularly.
4. Purchase a scale for daily weight monitoring; call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
5. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.
6. Follow up as needed for any concerns or changes in symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a male patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe, making it difficult for him to find a comfortable position. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father). He has been referred to a urologist by his primary care doctor after a CT scan revealed a kidney stone.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a urine strainer for the patient to collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes who presents with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. He first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient initially experienced stinging and burning sensations, which progressed to a foul smell and yellow drainage. He was started on antibiotics six days ago by his primary care provider. The patient reports that the wound has turned black around the outside and he has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. He also notes a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is very hot. The patient has a history of well-controlled diabetes with a hemoglobin A1c of 6.7, but has experienced blood sugar levels in the 300-400 range in the past two weeks.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes
Diabetic neuropathy

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever, chills.
Respiratory: Coughing, shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Right foot ulcer, calf muscle cramping.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot exam: Necrotic wound on right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, no bony exposure.
Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler).

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer.
- Medical Reasoning: Concern for infection and compromised blood supply to the wound.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current antibiotic therapy, obtain culture, and consider changing or adding antibiotics based on culture results. Perform debridement in the office today. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf. Follow up in 7 days.
- Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.

2. Diabetes management.
- Medical Reasoning: Recent blood sugar levels have been elevated.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current diabetes management, follow up with endocrinologist, and maintain hemoglobin A1c below 7.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a middle-aged male who presents with a tick bite on his right knee. He reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in the yard. The tick bite occurred over a week ago and has been causing burning and discomfort. The patient denies fever, chills, joint pain other than his typical arthritic pain, and difficulty moving his knee. He reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite. The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain or palpitations.
• Respiratory: No shortness of breath or cough.
• Musculoskeletal: Arthritic pain, tick bite on right knee.
• Neurological: Headache.
• Psychiatric: No anxiety or depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
• Musculoskeletal: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee. Full range of motion of right knee.
• Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
   • Medical Reasoning: Presence of bull's-eye rash and patient's report of feeling unwell since the tick bite.
   • Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports taking lisinopril and monitoring blood pressure at home.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily. Order lipid panel.

3. Diabetes.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports taking metformin and monitoring blood sugars, which are running in the 120s.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1c and basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
